title: 104_hr925
content:
The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise authority to prevent such limitations and property owners have the right to compensation. The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" mandates compensation for property owners if an agency action diminishes property value by 20% or more. If the value decreases by over 50%, the government can buy the affected portion. Once compensated, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation unless the compensation is refunded with inflation adjustment. SEC. 4. EFFECT OF STATE LAW.

If a use is a nuisance or prohibited under local zoning, no compensation shall be made under this Act.

SEC. 5. EXCEPTIONS.

No compensation for agency actions to prevent hazards to health, safety, or specific property damage. No compensation for agency actions under the Federal navigation servitude, except for wetlands.

SEC. 6. PROCEDURE. An owner seeking compensation under this Act must make a written request to the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate the compensation amount with the owner, and if no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or civil action. Arbitration procedures will follow those established under title 9, United States Code, and any award will include attorney's fees and arbitration costs to be promptly paid by the agency. An owner seeking compensation under this Act must make a written request to the agency within 180 days. If no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or civil action. The arbitration procedures will follow those established under title 9, United States Code, and any award will include attorney's fees and arbitration costs to be promptly paid by the agency. An owner who does not choose arbitration or does not receive prompt payment may obtain relief in a civil action against the agency. If the owner prevails in a civil action, they shall be entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on the compensation amount. Payments to owners and judgments obtained in civil actions shall be made from the agency's annual appropriation. Any payment or judgment obtained by an owner in a civil action under this section shall be made from the annual appropriation of the agency responsible. The agency may seek reimbursement from another agency if the action was a result of their requirement. If funds are insufficient, the agency head must seek appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act is subject to appropriations.

SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations and explain compensation procedures.

SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit compensation rights under the Constitution or other laws. Payment under this Act does not grant additional rights to the Federal Government.

SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The term "property" in this Act includes land and the right to use water. A use of property is limited by agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to the action. The term "agency action" includes making a grant to a public authority with conditions. The term "specified regulatory law" refers to specific environmental laws. The term "fair market value" refers to the most probable price at which property would change hands in a competitive market. This value is defined in relation to specific environmental laws such as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Food Security Act, the Reclamation Acts, the Federal Land Policy Management Act, and the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands in a competitive market between a willing buyer and seller. It is relevant in various environmental laws such as the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, the Endangered Species Act, the Food Security Act, the Reclamation Acts, the Federal Land Policy Management Act, and the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974. Additionally, the term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories, while the term "law of the State" encompasses laws of political subdivisions within a State. The House of Representatives passed the document on March 3, 1995, as attested by Robin H. Carle, Clerk.
